Text: Deliver me from my enemies, O my God; set me on high from those who rise up against me.
Context: The superscription of Psalm 59, before verse 1, is a plea for deliverance and implies anticipation for God’s intervention.

Text: Deliver me from my enemies, O God; protect me from those who rise up against me.
Context: David is asking for protection, indicating fear of his enemies.

Text: Deliver me from workers of iniquity, and save me from men of bloodshed.
Context: There is a strong aversion toward the violent actions of his enemies, hence the negative polarity and anger.

Text: For behold, they lie in wait for my life; fierce men conspire against me without cause or offense to them.
Context: David describes a treacherous situation, highlighting the unprovoked nature of the attack, which causes fear.

Text: O LORD, I have not transgressed or sinned; without fault, they run and prepare. Awake to help me, and see!
Context: Despite David‘s innocence, his enemies still pursue him. His call to the Lord to ”Awake“ implies anticipation for God’s assistance.

Text: And You, O LORD God of Hosts, the God of Israel, awake to punish all the nations; show no mercy to any wicked traitors. Selah
Context: David calls upon God to punish the wicked, showing his indignation.

Text: They return at evening, snarling like dogs and prowling around the city.
Context: The imagery of enemies as snarling dogs highlights their persistent antagonism, which is viewed negatively.

Text: See what they spew from their mouths—sharp words from their lips: ”For who can hear us?“
Context: Their arrogant speech and disrespect are detestable, increasing the negative emotion.

Text: But You, O LORD, laugh at them; You scoff at all the nations.
Context: The perspective shifts to God‘s view, showing His dominion and control over the situation, hence the positive polarity.

Text: O my Strength, I watch for You; for God is my fortress.
Context: David expresses confidence and trust in God, who is described as a fortress.

Text: My God in His lovingkindness will meet me; God will let me look in triumph on my foes.
Context: The assurance of God’s loving support gives a very positive tone to this verse.

Text: Do not kill them, or my people will forget; scatter them by Your power, and bring them down, O Lord, our shield.
Context: While there is a pleading for justice, there is also an underlying desire that people would remember and learn from the consequences given to the wicked.

Text: For the sin of their mouths and the words of their lips, let them be trapped in their pride, and for the curses and lies they utter.
Context: The desire for retribution against the lies and pride of David‘s enemies is strong in this verse.

Text: Consume them in wrath; consume them till they are no more. Then it will be known to the ends of the earth that God rules over Jacob. Selah
Context: The intensity of the call for divine judgment reflects a high level of negative emotion aimed at the eradication of the wicked.

Text: They return at evening, snarling like dogs and prowling around the city.
Context: This repeats the earlier imagery of enemies as dogs to emphasize their relentless harassment.

Text: They wander about for food and howl if not satisfied.
Context: The depiction of the enemies’ desperation and insatiable nature has a negative tone.

Text: But I will sing of Your strength and proclaim Your lovingkindness in the morning. For You have been to me a fortress and a refuge in the day of my distress.
Context: The contrast between the behavior of enemies and David‘s own response of worship underscores his positive attitude and sense of joy.

Text: O my Strength, I sing praises to You; for God is my fortress—my loving God.
Context: The repetition of trust and love for God provides a positive end to the psalm.
